sub_topic: Solving nonlinear equations using Newton-Raphson method
message_1: Using the Newton-Raphson method, find the root of the equation f(x) = x^3 - 6x^2 + 11x - 6, accurate to 3 decimal places, with an initial guess of x=1.5.
message_2:
To use the Newton-Raphson method, we first need to find the derivative of the function f(x) = x^3 - 6x^2 + 11x - 6. 

The derivative, f'(x), is:
f'(x) = 3x^2 - 12x + 11

Now, we will apply the Newton-Raphson formula iteratively until we reach the desired accuracy of 3 decimal places. The formula is:

x_new = x_old - f(x_old) / f'(x_old)

We start with the initial guess of x = 1.5:

Iteration 1:
x_old = 1.5
f(x_old) = (1.5)^3 - 6(1.5)^2 + 11(1.5) - 6 = -0.875
f'(x_old) = 3(1.5)^2 - 12(1.5) + 11 = -1.5
x_new = 1.5 - (-0.875) / (-1.5) = 1.083

Iteration 2:
x_old = 1.083
f(x_old) = (1.083)^3 - 6(1.083)^2 + 11(1.083) - 6 ≈ 0.025
f'(x_old) = 3(1.083)^2 - 12(1.083) + 11 ≈ 2.678
x_new = 1.083 - 0.025 / 2.678 ≈ 1.076

Iteration 3:
x_old = 1.076
f(x_old) = (1.076)^3 - 6(1.076)^2 + 11(1.076) - 6 ≈ 0.001
f'(x_old) = 3(1.076)^2 - 12(1.076) + 11 ≈ 2.751
x_new = 1.076 - 0.001 / 2.751 ≈ 1.076

At this point, the change in x is less than 0.001, so we can stop the iterations. The root of the equation f(x) = x^3 - 6x^2 + 11x - 6, accurate to 3 decimal places, is approximately x = 1.076.
